items.title: Apple puts Vision Pro exec in charge of Siri in exec shakeup
items.summary:
- Apple appoints Mike Rockwell, VP of the Vision Products Group, to lead the Siri team.
- Current AI head John Giannandrea is removed due to loss of confidence in his product development execution.
- Rockwell will report to software chief Craig Federighi, while Paul Meade takes over the Vision Products Group.
- Siri struggles against modern AI, prompting Apple to integrate third-party services like ChatGPT.
- Recent tests revealed Siri's inability to answer simple questions, and the rollout of personalized Siri features is delayed until next year.

items.title: Next Insurance gets scooped up by Munich Re for $2.6B
items.author: Mary Ann Azevedo
items.summary:
- Munich Re acquires Next Insurance for $2.6 billion.
- Next Insurance, based in Palo Alto, focuses on insurance for small-to-medium-sized businesses.
- The deal is expected to close in Q3 2025, subject to approvals.
- Next Insurance was last valued at $2.5 billion in late 2023 after raising $265 million.
- The company had over 600,000 customers and reported a revenue of $548 million in 2024.

items.title: Tesla Superchargers: GM, Ford, Rivian, and other EV brands with access
items.summary:
- In May 2023, Ford made a deal to give EV owners access to Tesla's Supercharger network.
- By the end of 2023, major automakers like GM, Hyundai, and Rivian also agreed to adopt Tesla’s North American Charging Standard (NACS).
- As of February 2024, Ford customers officially gained access, but adapter delivery faced delays.
- GM updated its vehicles to allow access by September 2024, requiring a $225 adapter for earlier models.
- Honda announced NACS access for its EVs by June 2025, with future models to be built with NACS ports.
- Rivian gained access to Superchargers in March 2024, with adapters sent to customers starting April.
- Volvo and Polestar began offering Tesla Supercharger access in October 2024, including free adapters for new EV buyers.

items.title: AI’s answers on China differ depending on the language, analysis finds
items.author: Kyle Wiggers
items.summary:
- AI models from Chinese labs like [DeepSeek](https://techcrunch.com/2025/03/14/deepseek-everything-you-need-to-know-about-the-ai-chatbot-app/) censor politically sensitive topics due to a 2023 law. 
- A developer, using the handle "xlr8harder", found that AI responses differ when questions are asked in different languages, particularly when addressing politically sensitive topics. 
- Models like Alibaba's [Qwen 2.5 72B Instruct](https://techcrunch.com/2025/03/20/ais-answers-on-china-differ-depending-on-the-language-analysis-finds/) were compliant in English but less so in Chinese; others like [R1 1776](https://www.perplexity.ai/fr/hub/blog/open-sourcing-r1-1776) also showed significant differences. 
- Experts noted these discrepancies could be due to varying amounts of training data and the influence of political censorship on AI model training.

items.title: Honda and Acura EV owners to gain access to Tesla Superchargers this June
items.author: Rebecca Bellan
items.summary:
- Honda and Acura EV owners will have access to Tesla's Supercharger network starting June.
- Owners of Honda Prologue and Acura ZDX will need to purchase Honda-approved charging adapters due to differences in charging port technology.
- Honda agreed in 2023 to adopt Tesla’s NACS standard and will release a new EV model in 2025 built with this standard.
- Notifications for adapter availability will be sent via HondaLink and Acura EV apps, which will also show Supercharger locations.

items.title: Gmail’s new AI search now sorts emails by relevance instead of chronological order
items.author: Aisha Malik
items.summary:
- Google announces a new update for Gmail that sorts emails by relevance instead of chronological order.
- AI will consider factors such as recency, most-clicked emails, and frequent contacts to improve search results.
- A toggle feature allows users to choose between “Most relevant” or “Most recent” email displays.
- The update is being rolled out globally for personal Google account users and is available on the web and mobile apps.
- This change aims to compete with Apple’s Mail app, which has introduced similar features recently.

items.title: CoreWeave prices its IPO to raise at least $2.2 billion. And now the games begin.
items.summary:
- CoreWeave is pricing its initial public shares between $47 and $55 per share, aiming to raise between $2.2 billion and $2.6 billion.
- Initially, the company hoped to raise at least $3 billion, potentially exceeding $4 billion.
- Pricing strategies often involve setting a lower initial range to create demand and excitement ahead of trading.
- CoreWeave secured a $12 billion customer agreement with OpenAI and appointed Meg Whitman to its board of directors recently.

items.title: Anthropic adds web search to its Claude chatbot
items.author: Kyle Wiggers
items.summary:
- Anthropic's AI chatbot Claude can now perform web searches, a previously unavailable feature.
- Web search is currently in preview for paid users in the U.S.; support for free users and additional countries will follow.
- Users can enable web search in their profile settings from the Claude web app, which will provide direct citations for information.
- This feature allows Claude to offer answers based on real-time insights, positioning it on par with competitors like ChatGPT, Google’s Gemini, and others.
- There are risks involved, such as the potential for hallucinations or incorrect citations from web sources, which is a common issue among chatbots.

items.title: OpenAI upgrades its transcription and voice-generating AI models
items.author: Kyle Wiggers
items.summary:
- OpenAI introduces new transcription and voice-generating models, enhancing its API capabilities.
- The text-to-speech model, gpt-4o-mini-tts, enables developers to customize the tone and style of speech.
- New speech-to-text models, gpt-4o-transcribe and gpt-4o-mini-transcribe, replace the older Whisper model, providing improved accuracy, especially in noisy environments.
- OpenAI won’t release the new models for open use, stating they are larger and necessitate careful consideration for an open-source release.
- Internal benchmarks show the new transcription models struggle with certain languages, obtaining a word error rate of nearly 30% for languages like Tamil and Telugu.

items.title: Threads adds new features to highlight topics and limit replies
items.author: Ivan Mehta
items.summary:
- Meta's Threads rolls out new features to enhance user engagement and content relevance.
- Users can now add up to 10 topics of interest to their profiles for better post suggestions.
- New reply controls allow only followers to respond to specific posts, building on quote control features launched previously.
- Redesigned topic tags introduced for easier navigation of interest-based content.
- Enhanced video playback features include a more user-friendly player with better control options.
- Meta is reintroducing political content suggestions based on user preferences after a previous halt.

items.title: Rerun’s open-source AI platform for robots, drones and cars revs up with $17M seed
items.author: Mike Butcher
items.summary:
- Rerun, a Stockholm-based startup, secured $17 million in seed funding for its open-source platform designed for 'Physical AI'.
- The funding round was led by Point Nine capital, increasing total funding to $20.2 million.
- Rerun's platform manages multimodal data including video, 3D scenes, and more to aid AI in physical environments, addressing issues between AI and physical data integration.
- Its tools enable better debugging by allowing developers to visualize bot movements and data from real-world sensors.
- The company aims to create a 'data flywheel' for improved AI training outcomes as more robots are deployed.
- Rerun's visualizations have been utilized in projects by Meta, Google, and Hugging Face, among others.
- The startup's team includes veterans from major tech companies like Apple, AWS, and Unity, focusing on specialized tools for AI developers.

items.title: Bluesky makes it easier for publishers to track referrals
items.author: Sarah Perez
items.summary:
- Bluesky has introduced a change to help publishers track referral traffic from posts on its platform.
- Links shared on Bluesky now pass through the “go” subdomain, allowing publishers to easily identify traffic coming from there.
- Reports show increased referral traffic from Bluesky, surpassing that from platforms like Threads and X for some publishers.
- Major news outlets like The Boston Globe and The Guardian have reported significant traffic increases from Bluesky.
- Bluesky’s approach allows better visibility for links, contrasting with other platforms that de-promote shared links.

items.title: X sues India over ‘unrestrained censorship’
items.summary:
- Elon Musk-owned X is suing the Indian government for unlawfully expanding its powers to remove online content.
- The lawsuit follows prior government orders to remove content, which X complied with despite filing a legal challenge.
- X accuses the government of creating an unlawful mechanism for removing content that bypasses legal safeguards.
- The company seeks to quash the directive amid ongoing state censorship efforts.
- A court hearing was held earlier this month; another is expected next week in Karnataka's High Court.

items.title: Nvidia thinks AI can solve electrical grid problems caused by AI
items.author: Tim De Chant
items.summary:
- Nvidia is partnering with EPRI to use AI for addressing electrical grid challenges caused by increased power demand from AI.
- The Open Power AI Consortium will deploy domain-specific AI models and make them open source for research purposes.
- Electricity demand is expected to rise by 4% annually, almost doubling from 2023 figures, largely driven by data center needs.
- The consortium includes major players like PG&E, Con Edison, Microsoft, and Oracle, focusing on renewable energy solutions.
- New strategies, such as load shifting during peak demands, could potentially unlock an additional 76 GW of capacity in the U.S.

items.title: One of Tesla’s top Wall Street supporters says Elon Musk faces a ‘moment of truth’
items.author: Sean O’Kane
items.summary:
- Analyst Dan Ives from Wedbush warns Elon Musk is facing a 'moment of truth' due to a crisis created by his political involvement, particularly with DOGE.
- Ives expressed concern over Tesla's stock price, which has dropped to around $230, less than half of its peak.
- Calls for Musk to balance his roles at DOGE and Tesla, and to provide a clearer roadmap for new affordable models and robotaxi services.

items.title: Hackers are ramping up attacks using year-old ServiceNow security bugs to target unpatched systems
items.author: Carly Page
items.summary:
- Hackers exploiting three ServiceNow vulnerabilities (CVE-2024-4879, CVE-2024-5178, CVE-2024-5217).
- Vulnerabilities disclosed in May 2024 and patched in July 2024.
- 70% of recent activity targeted systems in Israel; also observed in Germany, Japan, and Lithuania.
- Vulnerabilities can provide full database access to ServiceNow instances.
- ServiceNow reports no observed customer impact from attacks.
- Targeted sectors include private companies and government agencies worldwide.

items.title: Airbyte launches new connectors to help companies better leverage their data
items.author: Michel Tricot, Jean Lafleur
items.summary:
- Open-source data movement company [Airbyte](https://airbyte.com/) is launching new connectors for enterprises to utilize data effectively in the age of AI.
- New features include support for unstructured data transfer from Google Drive and SharePoint, along with compatibility with [Apache Iceberg](https://iceberg.apache.org/).
- A new connector bundle for enterprise customers includes data connector pipelines for applications like NetSuite, SAP, ServiceNow, and Workday.
- Airbyte provides enterprises with control over their data, allowing them to protect sensitive information during data transfer.
- The company was founded in 2020 and has raised over $181 million in venture capital, serving more than 7,000 enterprise customers.

items.title: VC investment in European startups passed $52B in 2024, continuing long-term growth trend
items.author: Mike Butcher
items.summary:
- Venture capital investment in European startups surpassed $52 billion in 2024, marking a long-term growth trend.
- The report by Orrick indicates stabilization after the peaks of 2021-2022 and the slump of 2023.
- European startups are increasing despite political and regulatory challenges, with funding shortages noted in the previous year.
- Adoption of British Venture Capital Association's new model documents has been significant, facilitating smoother deal-making across Europe.
- Over 70% of equity financings included a top-up, reflecting a focus on scaling rather than early sales.
- Average deal sizes grew by 66%, indicating improved deal volume and value.
- Equity-based deals are favored over debt-based, with 30% of rounds involving secondary financing.
- SaaS/platform models accounted for 21% of financings, while DeepTech and AI/ML represented 23% and 33% respectively in European deals.

items.title: Vote for Your Favorite Speaker at TechCrunch Sessions: AI
items.summary:
- TechCrunch Sessions: AI is on June 5 at Zellerbach Hall, UC Berkeley.
- Voting for speakers is open until March 21 at 11:59 p.m. PT.
- Six finalists include Mahesh Chayel, Cristina Mancini, and others focusing on various AI topics.

items.title: Solar notches another win as Microsoft adds 475 MW to power its AI data centers
items.author: Tim De Chant
items.summary:
- Microsoft adds 475 MW to its renewable power portfolio for data centers.
- Agreement made with AES for three solar projects in Illinois, Michigan, and Missouri.
- Microsoft has a growing renewable portfolio with over 34 GW of capacity, emphasizing the need for quick power sources due to rising computing demands.
- Recent trends show an increasing interest in nuclear power but renewables like solar remain more cost-effective and faster to deploy.
- Hybrid power plants combining solar and battery storage are emerging as competitive options against traditional power generation.

items.title: Tesla recalls Cybertrucks for exterior panels that fall off
items.author: Sean O'Kane
items.summary:
- Tesla recalls approximately 46,000 Cybertrucks due to a potential issue with exterior steel trim panels that can peel off while driving.
- The recall is a response to warranty claims and a safety hazard identified by the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (NHTSA).
- Tesla plans to use a different structural adhesive and a nut to secure the panels during the recall repair, which will be performed at no cost to owners.
- This is the eighth recall for the Cybertruck, following several past issues related to adhesive failures and other components coming loose.
- The recall was agreed upon on March 11, after further investigation into customer complaints sparked by NHTSA.

items.title: Spotify debuts ‘Concerts Near You’ playlists for discovering nearby shows
items.author: Lauren Forristal
items.summary:
- Spotify launched a new playlist called “Concerts Near You” to help users discover upcoming local concerts.
- The playlist is updated weekly with 30 songs from artists performing nearby, along with event details and ticket links.
- Users can tailor their playlist based on their listening habits and should share their location to receive updates.

items.title: Make waves in 2025: Exhibit at TechCrunch events
items.summary:
- Amplify your brand by exhibiting at TechCrunch events to reach thousands of attendees and decision-makers.
- Events include: [TechCrunch Sessions: AI](https://techcrunch.com/events/tc-sessions-ai/?utm_source=tc&utm_medium=post&utm_campaign=tcsessionsai&utm_content=post_exhibitorprogram_03202025&promo=post_exhibitorprogram_03202025&display=) on June 5, [TechCrunch All Stage](https://techcrunch.com/events/techcrunch-all-stage-2025/?utm_source=tc&utm_medium=post&utm_campaign=tcallstage2025&utm_content=exhibitorprogram&promo=post_exhibitorprogram_03202025&display=) on July 15, and [TechCrunch Disrupt 2025](https://techcrunch.com/events/tc-disrupt-2025/?utm_source=tc&utm_medium=post&utm_campaign=disrupt2025&utm_content=exhibitorprogram&promo=post_exhibitorprogram_03202025&display=) on October 27-29.
- Exhibiting provides full access to attendee perks, includes exhibit space, brand exposure, ticket bundles, and access to leads.
- Space is limited, urging early reservations for exhibitors.

items.title: Adapty releases a web-based solution for app makers to earn money outside app stores
items.author: Ivan Mehta
items.summary:
- Adapty launches FunnelFox to help app makers acquire customers via web experiences and quizzes.
- FunnelFox allows app makers to bypass App Store fees by directing customers to download their app after payment.
- Adapty tracked $20 million in revenue during testing with 100 customers, reportedly doubling their revenue from mobile in-app purchases.
- The company offers features like drag-and-drop tools and AI suggestions for building customer acquisition funnels.
- Adapty operates on a revenue-sharing model with tiered pricing for FunnelFox not yet specified.
- The startup is profitable and has raised $2.5 million in capital, tracking $1.2 billion in revenue across 10,000 applications.

items.title: Meta AI is finally coming to the EU, but with limitations
items.summary:
- Meta AI is launching in the EU with limited features compared to the U.S. version.
- Features include a chatbot function available in six languages, but creative functions like image generation are not included.
- The rollout extends to 27 EU countries and an additional 14 European nations, plus 21 overseas territories.
- Meta has faced regulatory challenges regarding data usage for training AI due to GDPR privacy regulations.
- The EU version of Meta AI was not trained on local user data, and therefore will not seek user consent.

items.title: TikTok to start pushing Amber Alerts to users’ For You feeds
items.author: Aisha Malik
items.summary:
- TikTok partners with the National Center for Missing & Exploited Children (NCMEC) to deliver Amber Alerts in users’ For You feeds in the U.S.
- Alerts will activate based on users' location via IP address and include key details like child’s photo and last known location.
- Nationwide launch follows a successful pilot in Texas with over 20 million views and 2.5 million visits to NCMEC’s website from August to December 2024.
- TikTok is donating advertising credits to help amplify NCMEC’s messaging on missing children and youth safety.
- The initiative aims to leverage TikTok's massive teen user base, potentially increasing awareness and responsiveness to Amber Alerts.

items.title: Pruna AI open sources its AI model optimization framework
items.author: Romain Dillet
items.summary:
- Pruna AI has open-sourced its AI model optimization framework, which utilizes various efficiency methods like caching, pruning, quantization, and distillation.
- Co-founder John Rachwan highlights the framework's ability to evaluate quality loss post-compression and improve model performance.
- The framework aims to simplify the use and combination of multiple compression methods, unlike typical single-method open-source tools.
- Pruna AI focuses on supporting image and video generation models but accommodates various model types.
- The company has raised $6.5 million in seed funding with notable investors and offers both open-source and enterprise solutions for AI model optimization.

items.title: Evroc Raises $55M to Build Hyperscale Cloud in Europe
items.summary:
- Evroc, a Swedish startup, has raised €50.6 million ($55 million) in Series A funding to create a secure and sustainable hyperscale cloud in Europe.
- The funding aims to establish eight data centers by 2028, with two facilities already operational in Stockholm and Paris.
- The company plans to open two additional facilities in Frankfurt by mid-2025 and is focused on AI workloads in its upcoming data centers, expected to be completed by 2026.

items.title: ChatGPT Hit with Privacy Complaint Over Defamatory Hallucinations
items.summary:
- OpenAI faces a new privacy complaint in Europe about ChatGPT's false information generation.
- A Norwegian individual was falsely claimed to have been convicted of murdering his children.
- Noyb, a privacy rights group, argues ChatGPT's errors violate GDPR's requirement for accurate personal data.
- The individual has a right to rectification under EU law, but OpenAI provides no means to correct such errors.
- Confirmed GDPR breaches can incur fines of up to 4% of global annual turnover.
- Previous GDPR interventions have led to changes in ChatGPT's operations following similar complaints.

items.title: Michael Seibel is leaving Y Combinator
items.author: Loizos
items.summary:
- Michael Seibel announced he is moving to a “partner emeritus” role at Y Combinator after over 12 years.
- Seibel has been part of YC since his time as a founder, having gone through the program twice.
- He previously served as a group partner, managing director, and CEO of the accelerator.
- The transition follows a previous step back into a less operational role, indicated in a blog post last year.
- His departure may be linked to changes in leadership when Garry Tan became CEO in 2022.
- Seibel plans to take the summer off and then focus on government initiatives.

items.title: ClearGrid, armed with a fresh $10M, is developing AI to improve debt collection in MENA
items.author: Mohammed Al Zaben, Khalid Bin Bader Al Saud, Mohammed Khalili
items.summary:
- ClearGrid, a Dubai-based startup, has raised $10 million to modernize debt collection in emerging markets using AI.
- The company aims to help banks and fintechs recover debts without customer harassment, targeting the outdated practices in the industry.
- Founded in May 2023 by Mohammed Al Zaben and his co-founders, ClearGrid processes borrower accounts via its platform, with 95% of operations fully automated.
- Its AI models can predict repayment likelihood and personalize outreach, significantly improving recovery rates compared to traditional collection agencies.
- ClearGrid claims a 30% increase in recovery rates and a 50% reduction in collection costs for partnered banks and fintechs.
- The startup is currently profitable in the UAE and plans to expand its operations to Saudi Arabia.

items.title: SoftBank to acquire semiconductor designer Ampere in $6.5B all-cash deal
items.author: Kate Park
items.summary:
- SoftBank Group will acquire Ampere Computing for $6.5 billion in cash.
- The acquisition aims to enhance SoftBank's investment in AI infrastructure.
- Ampere will operate as a wholly-owned subsidiary, with the deal expected to close in the second half of 2025.
- Major shareholders Carlyle and Oracle will sell their stakes, comprising over 90% of Ampere's ownership.
- Ampere, founded in 2017, employs about 1,000 engineers and specializes in high-performance computing chips based on ARM technology.
- This acquisition follows a series of recent investments by SoftBank in AI-related projects and technologies.

items.title: How a $6M bet on Wiz turned into a massive 200x return for one early backer
items.author: Marina Temkin
items.summary:
- Wiz was acquired by Alphabet for $32 billion, promising large returns for investors.
- Sequoia Capital, an early investor, stands to make $3 billion, around 25x their investment.
- Cyberstarts invested $6.4 million in Wiz's seed round, expecting to make $1.3 billion, a return of 222x.
- Cyberstarts has total returns of $1.42 billion, including earlier share sales.
- Index Ventures, another major backer, will profit over $3.8 billion from the deal.

items.title: OpenAI’s o1-pro is the company’s most expensive AI model yet
items.author: Kyle Wiggers
items.summary:
- OpenAI has launched a more powerful version of its o1 AI model called o1-pro in its developer API.
- The pricing for o1-pro is $150 per million input tokens and $600 per million generated tokens, making it significantly more expensive than previous models.
- Early impressions of o1-pro have been mixed, with issues reported handling certain tasks like Sudoku puzzles.
- Despite slight performance improvements over o1 on coding and math problems, the overall feedback has not been overwhelmingly positive.

items.title: Hacked, leaked, exposed: Why you should never use stalkerware apps
items.summary:
- Stalkerware apps are designed for spying on partners, with over 25 known hacked companies since 2017.
- The SpyX breach compromised the data of nearly 2 million victims, following previous breaches like Cocospy and mSpy.
- Stalkerware companies often market their products for illegal surveillance, creating significant risks for victims' personal data.

items.title: Data breach at stalkerware SpyX affects close to 2 million, including thousands of Apple users
items.summary:
- A data breach at consumer-grade spyware SpyX affected nearly 2 million people, including many Apple users.
- The breach occurred in June 2024 but was reported only recently, with no communication to affected customers.
- The leaked data included 1.97 million records, most associated with SpyX and its clones MSafely and SpyPhone.
- About 40% of the email addresses were already listed in Have I Been Pwned.
- The breach featured plaintext Apple Account usernames and passwords, raising security concerns for Apple users.
- Google removed a Chrome extension linked to SpyX to uphold store policies against unauthorized surveillance apps.

items.title: X users treating Grok like a fact-checker spark concerns over misinformation
items.summary:
- Users on Elon Musk’s X are seeking fact-checking from Musk’s AI bot Grok, raising misinformation concerns.
- In March 2025, X allowed users to ask Grok questions, initiating experiments with user-generated inquiries, particularly in politically charged contexts.
- Fact-checkers worry that Grok can produce convincing yet potentially incorrect answers, exacerbating misinformation issues observed in prior instances.
- Previous calls by five state secretaries urged Musk to enhance Grok's operations post misinformation incidents during U.S. electoral events.
- Unlike AI, human fact-checkers rely on credible sources and bear accountability, addressing transparency issues that AI lacks.
- Concerns arise regarding Grok's misrepresentation of information and its lack of disclaimers, leading to unverified claims.
- There is skepticism about Grok's training data and quality control measures, impacting how it interprets user posts for valid responses.
- Social media dynamics allow misleading information to spread rapidly, raising awareness of its potential social consequences.
- Research shows AI can have error rates of up to 20%, leading to significant real-world repercussions when incorrect information is propagated.
- The role of human fact-checkers remains vital despite advancements in AI, with efforts to incorporate crowdsourced verification models ongoing.

items.title: Sequoia shutters Washington, D.C., office, lets go of policy team
items.author: Dominic-Madori Davis
items.summary:
- Sequoia will close its Washington, D.C., office and dissolve its policy team by the end of March.
- This decision contrasts with other VC firms like Andreessen Horowitz, which are enhancing their political connections.
- Sequoia opened its D.C. office five years ago to assist companies with regulatory matters and improve relationships with policymakers.
- The policy team's efforts have led Sequoia to feel prepared to continue these relationships without a dedicated function.
- The closure affects policy fellows and three full-time employees at the firm.

items.title: Sequoia shutters D.C. office, lets go of policy team
items.author: Dominic-Madori Davis
items.summary:
- Sequoia will close its D.C. office and let go of its policy team by the end of March.
- This decision contrasts with other Silicon Valley VC firms like Andreessen Horowitz, which are enhancing their policy teams.
- Sequoia's D.C. office was opened five years ago to assist companies with regulatory challenges.
- The firm claims it is well-positioned to maintain relationships in the U.S. and Europe.
- The closure affects policy fellows and three full-time employees.

items.title: OpenAI research lead Noam Brown thinks AI ‘reasoning’ models could’ve arrived decades ago
items.author: Kyle Wiggers
items.summary:
- Noam Brown, leading AI reasoning research at OpenAI, believes reasoning AI models could have emerged 20 years earlier with the right approaches.
- Speaking at Nvidia’s GTC conference, Brown highlighted the importance of reasoning in AI, inspired by human thought processes.
- Brown is a key figure behind the o1 model, which employs test-time inference to enhance reasoning capabilities in AI.
- While pre-training remains relevant, AI labs are increasingly focusing on complementing it with test-time inference.
- He noted the growing challenges for academia in scaling experiments due to limited computing resources but emphasized potential collaborations with labs.
- Brown criticized the current state of AI benchmarks, calling for improvements that do not require extensive computing power.

items.title: Nvidia reportedly acquires synthetic data startup Gretel
items.author: Alex Watson, Laszlo Bock, John Myers, Ali Golshan
items.summary:
- Nvidia has acquired Gretel, a synthetic AI training data startup based in San Diego.
- The acquisition terms remain undisclosed; however, it is estimated to be valued in the nine figures, surpassing Gretel's last valuation of $320 million.
- Gretel, which was founded in 2019, employs around 80 people, and its technology will integrate with Nvidia's generative AI services.
- The startup had raised over $67 million in venture capital from prominent investors.
- This acquisition aligns with the trend where major tech companies are utilizing synthetic data for AI model training due to diminishing real-world data sources.

items.title: AWS Generative AI Executive Raj Aggarwal Leaves to Launch New Startup
items.author: Raj Aggarwal
items.summary:
- Raj Aggarwal leaves AWS after nearly three years as GM of generative AI and revenue acceleration.
- He claimed achievements include the launch of large-scale generative AI products that increased pipeline generation by 4.9%.
- Aggarwal plans to start a new company, returning to his entrepreneurial roots, without providing specific details.
- Previously founded Localytics and Demand Sage, both of which raised significant venture funding before exits.

items.title: Group co-led by Fei-Fei Li suggests that AI safety laws should anticipate future risks
items.author: Fei-Fei Li, Jennifer Chayes, Mariano-Florentino Cuéllar
items.summary:
- A California policy group co-led by Fei-Fei Li recommends that AI laws address unseen future risks.
- The report released on March 19, 2025, comes from the Joint California Policy Working Group on Frontier AI Models, organized by Governor Gavin Newsom.
- It advocates for transparency from AI model developers regarding safety tests and data practices.
- The report stresses that AI policy should anticipate future threats, similar to predicting nuclear weapon harm without witnessing its effects.
- A two-pronged strategy of 'trust but verify' is recommended for AI developers to enhance safety accountability.
- The report was positively received across the ideological spectrum of AI safety advocates and policymakers, indicating potential support for future legislation.

items.title: Substack rival Ghost is now connected to the fediverse
items.author: Sarah Perez
items.summary:
- Newsletter platform [Ghost](https://ghost.org/) integrates with the fediverse, enhancing connectivity with the open social web.
- The integration allows Ghost Pro subscribers to share and promote blog posts across federated apps like [Mastodon](https://techcrunch.com/2023/07/24/what-is-mastodon/), [Pixelfed](https://techcrunch.com/2025/01/14/decentralized-instagram-alternative-pixelfed-launches-mobile-apps/), and [Threads](https://techcrunch.com/2025/03/07/what-is-instagrams-threads-app-all-your-questions-answered/).
- Ghost's social web beta enables users to follow accounts, interact with posts, and utilize a reader for social feeds, with a more finalized integration expected in Ghost 6.0.

items.title: A key DeepMind robotics researcher left Google and Nvidia has already backed his stealth startup
items.author: Charles Rollet
items.summary:
- Pete Florence, a senior researcher at DeepMind, has left Google to establish a robotics startup named [Generalist AI](https://generalistai.com/).
- The startup has received backing from Nvidia, as announced during a panel at the GTC conference.
- Florence aims to develop general-purpose robots, stating a desire to reduce the marginal cost of physical labor to zero.
- Other DeepMind alumni have similarly founded companies in robotics and AI.

items.title: Bluesky made more money selling t-shirts mocking Zuckerberg than custom domains
items.author: Amanda Silberling
items.summary:
- Bluesky CEO Jay Graber wore a t-shirt mocking Mark Zuckerberg at SXSW, leading to high demand for sales.
- The company made more money in one day of t-shirt sales than in two years of custom domains sales.
- The t-shirts retail for $40 and feature the phrase "Mundus sine Caesaribus" as a rebuttal to Zuckerberg's "Aut Zuck aut nihil".
- Bluesky quickly sold out of the initial t-shirt printing and reopened orders for a week.
- Domain sales were not heavily promoted and not integrated into the Bluesky app, leading to low revenue.

items.title: xAI launches an API for generating images
items.author: Kyle Wiggers
items.summary:
- Elon Musk’s AI company, xAI, has launched an image generation API called "grok-2-image-1212."
- The model can generate up to 10 images per request, limited to 5 requests per second, at $0.07 per image.
- xAI’s pricing is comparable to partners and competitors, with Black Forest Labs charging around $0.05 per image and Ideogram $0.08.
- The API currently does not allow adjustments to image quality, size, or style, and prompts are subject to revision by a "chat model."
- xAI is reportedly seeking a $10 billion funding round, aiming for a valuation of $75 billion and is expanding its data center in Memphis.

items.title: Telegram founder Pavel Durov says app now has 1B users, calls WhatsApp a ‘cheap, watered down imitation’
items.author: Ivan Mehta
items.summary:
- Telegram founder Pavel Durov announced the app has surpassed 1 billion active users, up from 950 million last year.
- Last year, Telegram registered $547 million in profits and became profitable in December 2024.
- Durov criticized WhatsApp, labeling it as a cheap imitation of Telegram, and highlighted Telegram’s independence and growth despite competition.
- Outside of China, WhatsApp leads in chat platforms with over 2 billion monthly active users.
- Both platforms compete to attract businesses and creators with features like business accounts and channels.
- Telegram appeals to crypto enthusiasts by integrating the TON blockchain and enabling decentralized apps for various functionalities.

items.title: Elon Musk’s X reportedly bounces back to $44B valuation
items.summary:
- X's valuation has reportedly bounced back to **$44 billion** according to the **Financial Times**.
- Elon Musk purchased the platform (formerly Twitter) for $44 billion in 2022.
- A separate **Bloomberg** report indicates that X raised close to **$1 billion** in funding, valuing the company at around **$32 billion**.
- Musk himself participated in the equity raise.
- X's valuation dropped as low as **$10 billion** last September according to **Fidelity Investments**.
- Despite a revenue decline since Musk's takeover, X reported **$1.2 billion** in adjusted earnings for 2024.

items.title: Judge orders Citibank to release nonprofit funds, rejects EPA’s arguments
items.author: Tim De Chant
items.summary:
- A federal judge ruled the EPA acted arbitrarily in terminating contracts with three nonprofits immediately following funding freezes.
- The judge issued a temporary restraining order for the EPA and Citibank to allow access to the funds.
- The nonprofits had significant financial commitments, including Climate United's $392 million and Power Forward's $539 million, which were impacted by the funding freeze.
- The EPA provided vague reasons for contract terminations and failed to follow necessary procedures prior to account freezes.
